summary: This document is a chain of emails from June 2020 between FBI personnel and U.S. Attorney's Office prosecutors discussing logistical and technical challenges in processing and transferring digital evidence seized from Jeffrey Epstein's properties in New York and the U.S. Virgin Islands. The emails focus on coordinating a call, creating a master list of seized devices, and resolving issues with data format and accessibility for review.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the investigation; digital evidence was seized from his residences in New York and the U.S. Virgin Islands.

persons.name: Peter Nygard
persons.context: Mentioned alongside Epstein as a topic for a planned conference call between FBI and prosecutors.

connections.description: Both are subjects of investigation discussed in the same FBI-prosecutor coordination call.

events.title: Coordination call scheduled
events.description: FBI and SDNY prosecutors schedule a conference call to discuss Epstein and Nygard search warrant documents and ensure all parties are aligned.

events.title: Search of Epstein's NY properties
events.description: Search warrants executed at Epstein's New York residences, resulting in seizure of numerous digital devices.

events.title: Search of Epstein's USVI properties
events.description: Search warrants executed at Epstein's U.S. Virgin Islands residences, resulting in seizure of digital devices.

keyFacts: The FBI and SDNY were processing terabytes of digital evidence seized from Epstein's properties in New York and the U.S. Virgin Islands, including computers, servers, phones, tablets, and loose media.

Prosecutors expressed frustration over difficulties in reviewing the data due to formatting issues, inability to link emails to attachments, and lack of a clear inventory linking data to specific seized devices.
The case was described as 'top-driven on both sides (FBI and SDNY) due to the incredible amount of media attention it has received,' indicating high-level pressure.
A 2007 search of one of Epstein's properties was referenced, with 9 IDE hard drives from that search found in his Manhattan apartment during the 2019 searches.
The correspondence reveals internal coordination challenges between the FBI's Computer Analysis Response Team (CART) and prosecutors regarding evidence processing and transfer timelines.
